Params[3]: The snow has covered up the scarred earth by afternoon. Only a bloody figure can be seen inside this barren land, running above the upper-level carriage.

Mike, the heavily wounded Niino, and most of the civilians are staying on the lower level. To find out the fate of Rachel and the Cargo Crew, Noan travels five kilometers of snowfield alone, returning to the upper level.
No amount of snow can cover the blood and bodies here. At last, Noan finally finds the person he has been looking for.
Captain Rachel!
...Noan?
Rachel has lost her left hand as blood drips down her forehead. Noan has never seen her so vulnerable.
Your hand... Is there a doctor around?
...Ha. There's no one left. We've failed...
Turns out Ashlar has a few of those mechanoids hidden away.
In the end... we only got to catch a breath... when the aristocrats started to fight among themselves.
Among themselves...? You're talking about Ashlar and Princess Jamilah?
Yeah... Jamilah didn't win either... Her guards have gotten as quiet as this snow.
The only good news is... Ashlar has played all his cards now. Without his aces, he has fallen from his throne.
I'll take you to a base outside. We'll find a doctor. Hold on!
That's not necessary. It's too late now...
She forces a wry chuckle and gives Noan her terminal.
Captain...!
Listen to what I have to say.
Take my terminal. It's part of my deal with him...
What deal?
I hope he'll—I hope Ashlar will let you live.
There are also records of our businesses in there, things Ashlar wants to keep hidden.
Give him this terminal and my head, and you'll become the hero who quells the riot... The aristocrats will favor you and put you in charge of the Cargo Crew.
...What?
I'm almost out of breath. Don't make me repeat myself...
Why are you asking me to take over your place this way?!
Because we've failed. To get another shot, we'll need... time. Time to rest and rebuild.
If you give up here and now, what would happen... to those without a home?
No base will take them in. They have to stay on the train... with no one to look after them... And the aristocrats... will keep hurting and exploiting the people as they have always done...
You said Ashlar lost his aces! Now's the chance to take him down!
I wish... it was that simple. It's not just weapons that bond those aristocrats.
Even if our rebellion succeeded... it would have only been the first of many steps... There would be a lot of problems we have to solve. Alas, we failed, so we'll need to start again.
Rachel lowers her head, her face pale. She has lost too much blood.
Listen. They're coming to search the roof. Do it now, or it's going to be too late.
Captain Rachel! I won't do it!
Yes, you will!
She shouts, angry and frail, forcing Noan to grab her gun.
Hold it tight! Don't let go!
Didn't you want to find Field? There's information on him in the terminal... But you can only find him... if you survive this.
I've made my share of mistakes leading the Cargo Crew... I've done so much wrong and hurt too many people...
I didn't trust those I ought to believe in while trusting people like Assad...
Even when he let his people steal from their own team... when he himself did it... I allowed it... because he was trading half of his take... for our weapons.
So... what happened to Bancroft...
That's right... he was the one who told your friend about Warehouse G54. Assad tricked him and got him inside the crate... That's why you should hate me.
Shoot. Kill me and live...!
Remake the Cargo Crew the way you want. Don't make the mistakes I've made!
Quickly! They're almost here...!
But the Cargo Crew is almost wiped out! You might be wrong, but you're my mentor! How can I do this to you?!
Then... consider it my last wish, Noan.
I've always wanted... to atone for what I did to your mother...
She was dead because of me... The only way I can make it up to her is to make sure you get to live.
Rachel puts her hand over Noan's. Noan is about to hold her cold, shivering hand when he realizes she has something else in mind.
What are you doing?! Captain Rachel!
You know, Julie? I still l—
The flare from the barrel covers up her last words.
Noan is the last one standing on the snowy field.
After Rachel dies, Noan is quickly taken to the jail cell that once imprisoned his mother. He stays there for 14 days under many watchful eyes.

The guards all have their own agenda to patrol outside his cell. Some are people from Ashlar's side, while others are royal bodyguards rarely seen in these parts. Noan even sees a hurt, young Construct wandering nearby.
Some of them want the truth, while others want to make sure Noan tells their truth.
These people are all cautious of each other, their moves and countermoves forcing them into a deadlock. Somehow, that gives Noan the chance to survive.
The night before Noan is supposed to be brought to the temporary "council," the young wandering Construct suddenly sits in front of his cell when no one else is around.
Leader asked me to apologize on her behalf.
She wants to help, but the royal forces are hampered right now. The soldiers we sent were the most we could do.
And she wants to thank you. She knows you have Rachel's terminal, but you haven't given it up, have you?
...What are you saying?
Do what you want to do.
The next day, Noan is marched into the temporary "council" by the guards. Commoners surround the hall, whispering tales of the event and the survivors.
Royals and their bodyguards sit at the top of the staircase, while aristocrats with different expressions are sitting nearby. At the furthest right are "guests" Noan has never seen before.
Their outfits suggest they are Constructts from Babylonia—Noan has seen many of them while working for the Cargo Crew. He never talked to them outside of their dealings.
What happened to Asslam has deeply impacted the Akdilek Commercial Alliance. As our trade partner, Babylonia has requested to attend this trial.

Both Babylonia and ACA agree that the Cargo Crew and Bumblebee of the lower level are instrumental to our work to reclaim Earth. We have therefore allowed our citizens to sit in this meeting. They have the right to know.
You don't mind, do you?
Of course not.
Ashlar sounds confident.
Over the last three days, he has deployed various methods to search and question Noan, offering carrots and sticks to make sure that Rachel's terminal is not in Noan's possession.
To prevent Noan from hiding the terminal using his knowledge of the lower-level carriages, Ashlar's guards have been repeating one thing—

As long as Noan frames the event as a result of Rachel conspiring with the royals, Noan will be crowned the hero who quelled the riot. He will be in charge of the Cargo Crew and enjoy all the benefits that come with it.
If Noan does not follow their script, there is only one end that awaits him—he will be executed in the cruelest way possible. The people the Cargo Crew tried to protect will be exiled from the train.
Allow me to begin as I was the first to discover this riot.

The trigger of the event is as follows: my dutiful guards discovered that Rachel had stockpiled a large number of unregulated weaponry from unknown sources inside the storage carriage while inspecting their wares.
My guards were trying to inquire about the origins and purposes of these weapons when the Cargo Crew suddenly attacked them.
Ashlar lies loudly and proudly as if there were no wire inside the coat, Assad was not dragged to his death, and the people had not been held hostage at gunpoint.
During our follow-up investigations, we have secured a key witness. He was a core member of the Cargo Crew.
People turn their gaze toward where Ashlar is pointing—Noan.
According to his testimony, Captain Rachel conspired with the royals to allow the Cargo Crew to carry out an armed riot on the upper level to eliminate the voices of dissent.
Bullshit! No way Rachel would work with the aristocrats!
Don't you slander her!
Rachel never told the people the truth. She said these shadowy deals would break their hearts.
Face the truth! You filthy peasants! This tragedy only happened because the royals condoned the Cargo Crew's irresponsible and unrestrained behavior!
Therefore—
He suddenly raises his voice.

To prevent the royals from abusing their power again, I propose an end to the monarchy! We shall establish a parliament a la Babylonia, dividing the power and responsibilities among those of us who actually contribute!
Hear! Hear!
Cheers and applause from the aristocrats and their underlings erupt as if rehearsed.
Ashlar, you claimed that the royals condoned the Cargo Crew's actions. What exactly did they condone?
The stockpiling of unregulated weapons and not holding them accountable for their violent behavior.
Let's put aside the fact that you have yet to present concrete evidence. On the day of the conflict, you deployed a large number of lethal, military-grade weapons. Were you authorized to use them?
We simply sent our technicians to override the control of those deadly weapons. They were originally Rachel's.
Is that so? But I received the following piece of evidence earlier.
A manager from logistics named Barbra brought me a ledger and asked for my help, claiming that someone is trying to take her life.
You have apparently obtained many supplies and resources through her.
Anyone can forge a letter or a ledger.
That woman has passed. Who can say if you have falsified evidence post-mortem? We can't question the dead!
Ashlar's right!
Stop blaming us honest, dutiful folks! You despicable royals!
Ashlar's advocates immediately clamor for him, condemning Aston loudly.
(Barbra is dead... She didn't live even after she gave away Assad's recordings...)
Why don't we ask our key witness?
This young man here is our hero! Rachel might have raised him, but he was the one who put her down in the end! He was the one who stopped the riot!
Ashlar's words cause an uproar among the people in the back.
What did he just say? That kid killed Rachel?!
Isn't he the guy who always stayed near her?
How did that happen?! I thought we all did our best... but... it turns out...
Traitor! You filthy traitorous bastard!
Silence!
Ashlar waves his hand gleefully, gesturing for the guards to pacify the crowd.
When the council is quiet again, Ashlar makes his way toward Noan, his hands behind his back, his steps light and springy.
Now, tell us—how did Rachel get as far as she did?
Captain Rachel...
Asslam has always been in chaos. Everyone does what they can to survive this hellhole.
Trust Rachel. She has a plan to free us from this oppression.
Will she become a great leader? Just like the heroes in the books?
Yes. I'm trying to help her... I don't always agree with the way she does things, but I have no right to question her, either.
You'll be my apprentice starting today. I'll train you and teach you to protect yourself.
Like I've said before, the folks on the upper level are just going to work with someone else if we refuse to make these Blessing Boxes. That won't help with our situation at all.
We've tried strikes and protests... but at the end of the day, the aristocrats own this train. We won't get a say so long as they're still alive.
It's true that I've crossed the line, but if what I did brings about a better tomorrow for the people, I'd gladly do it again and pay the price.
The supplies for the weapons? Hmph. I have my ways.
They don't even consider that should the lower level keeps going like this, no one's escaping once the bubble bursts.
...I don't know why Field disappeared.
These sacrifices are made so that people get to live a good life!
I've always wanted... to atone for what I did to your mother...
Remake the Cargo Crew the way you want. Don't make the mistakes I've made!
Would Rachel work with Ashlar again if she could turn back time?
(Probably.)
She kept betting her hope on something more powerful than her—something she thought to be immovable, even on her last breath. She believed that power would save Noan.
Rachel has never really trusted us. She's become a tyrant while trying to get her weapons.
She's witnessed too many things she couldn't change and given up on too many she couldn't save. She stopped believing that she could save anyone.
How does that happen? Noan asks himself again.
This was my only choice. Otherwise, I wouldn't be able to change anything.
Does he have a choice now?
The Cargo Crew has messed us up real bad, kid, but Ashlar is willing to offer you mercy. You don't have a choice.
Do you want to end up like Assad? Kicked off the train and dragged to your death? And even if you're fine with dying yourself, are you willing to take down so many others with you?
Is that so?
He hears Jamilah's raised voice the moment he sets foot in the council.

Both Babylonia and ACA agree that the Cargo Crew and Bumblebee of the lower level are instrumental to our work to reclaim Earth. We have therefore allowed our citizens to sit in this meeting. They have the right to know.
Jamilah is not entirely unprepared. She is sending a subtle message.
—"They are important. Babylonia's partners also agree."
No businessmen will throw away anything they deem important.
So? Everyone's waiting for you.
Ashlar slams on the desk before Noan, looking at the whispering crowd impatiently.
In a brief moment of trance, Noan remembers something Field asked him a long, long time ago.
What do you want to be in the future, Noan?
Noan looks up and stares back at the eyes watching him, unyielding even if their gazes threaten to pierce him.
Now is the time to choose "the future." He knows his choice will spell his doom.
But he will not regret it as long as he can finish what the Cargo Crew started all those years ago. It is just a shame he cannot live to see it.
Rachel stockpiled those weapons because she wanted equal rights for the people on the lower level. She wanted to free us from being exploited by the Blessing Boxes and an unjust system.
And our worst oppressor is none other than Ashlar and his people.
This time was no different. Not only did he use military-grade weapons he secretly owned to slaughter the Cargo Crew, but he also sent his guards to come after the citizens in the damaged carriage.
Everyone standing back there can testify to that.
They are the survivors of that disaster. They might not know why it happened, but they have definitely witnessed what you did.
The people in the back are immediately stirred up, echoing Noan's statement out loud and railing against the cruel slaughter. Seeing this, Ashlar just sneers, unperturbed.
It seems that our little witness here has been coaxed into telling lies.
My fellow aristocrats. Do you remember why we funded Asslam all those years ago?
Love and hope. That's right. We did it because we wanted to spread love and hope around the world. Did what the Cargo Crew do align with our intention, then? Of course it didn't.
We all have to work hard in order to reclaim Earth and rebuild the glorious Golden Age. How shameful and selfish is it to destroy Asslam just because some of them are tired?
—In the grand scheme of things, no amount of pain of an individual is worth mentioning.
If Noan has not witnessed the struggles and sufferings on the lower level for the past 17 years, he might get to be as impartial and visionary as the aristocrats.
As the rehearsed cheers and applause die down, Noan plays his ace.
I still have Rachel's terminal.
What?!
I've gone through her records. 20 years of invoices, lists, messages, contracts, and minutes are all intact.
That will be enough to prove what you have done! That will show everyone who the real oppressor is and who has been trying to assassinate the aristocrats who wouldn't take your orders!
That's you, obviously.
—What?!
You're Julie's boy, aren't you? Your father used to work for me.
We still have records of his crime, I believe. Rachel killed him in revenge before we could give him his sentence.
Ashlar causes a commotion among the crowd again.
Your mother never stopped holding a grudge. She helped Rachel to manipulate the books and misappropriated supplies. We have all of them on record.
To avenge your parents, you stayed by Rachel's side all these years so as to steer her to start her riot at the wrong time and take the chance to kill her yourself!
The whole thing was in-fighting inside the Cargo Crew?
What else can those commoners do except for taking up our space and causing trouble?
They're all the same! Uneducated and vulgar! Violence is all they know!
Hear! Hear!
How horrible! Absolutely horrible!
The aristocrats all rise to support Ashlar even when he has just spun a brand new narrative out of thin air to shift all the blames onto Noan.
What are you all talking about?! He still hasn't shown any proof! Why are you all supporting him?!
Noan shouts, but the crowd follows where Ashlar leads, disregarding Noan's words.
Get these criminals out of here!
Make the train safe again!
Have you heard of the tale "Calling a Deer a Horse"?
Ashlar walks toward Noan nonchalantly, quietly teasing the young man.
A chancellor wanted to overthrow the king, but he didn't know how much sway he had in the court. So, before he acted, he gifted his king a deer while claiming it to be a horse.
The king didn't believe him, obviously. So the chancellor asked the other officials in the court, "Is this a deer or a horse?" And how do you think they answered?
So many couldn't wait to agree with the chancellor that it was indeed a horse.
You thought those who mistake a deer for a horse are stupid, but that's their cleverest trick. People who tell the truth... are often the first to die.
We have guests from Babylonia with us today, so I prefer not to make a scene. This is your last chance to hand in the terminal.
Noan's hand with the terminal will not stop shaking.
I've exposed you, and you don't want to "make a scene"?
They were working with me in the first place. As long as I "reassure" them afterward and provide them with "reasonable" proof, they will leave this place satisfied.
Reasonable...?!
Noan looks at Jamilah. She has not spoken after her initial speech. Lowering her head, she only whispers to the people beside her quietly as if the other figures behind her are a threat.
Noan turns to look at the unnamed Construct and Aston. Neither of them is able to answer Noan's helpless gaze as the crowd around them becomes more and more alarming.
Standing amidst this insurmountable tide, Noan finally accepts that the law and order of the Golden Age have utterly collapsed.
In this apocalypse, only the "leader" who holds actual power can make the rules that others follow. Ordinary people will not light up the night, as bright as they might burn.
Still, he wants to try one last time.
...Hey!
Noan raises his hand with the terminal and throws it toward the young Construct.
And then—
Several bullets are fired from the crowd, hitting Noan before his hand even drops.
Cough...
The pain in his chest and abdomen almost knocks him unconscious.

Params[1]: What is the meaning of this?

Params[3]: He seems to hear a voice—a question from the future asked through his memories.
...Meaning?
Noan tries to look up, but all he hears is the echoing chorus of Ashlar's rules.
—Is that because they worry they will otherwise become the next targets?
The guards surround the young Construct while the crowd chants. They cannot take the evidence away from the Construct, and the Construct cannot fight them off due to Jamilah's stance.

Params[1]: A futile attempt... You've made the wrong choice.

Params[3]: ...As long as... the people's dream...

Params[1]: Do you think that "evidence" will help you achieve the dream of the Cargo Crew?

Params[3]: The distant voice sneers.
Through his blurred vision, Noan can see a bullet hitting the terminal inside the Construct's hand.
The terminal shatters, its pieces scattered on the floor, stepped over by the disorderly crowd.

Params[1]: Their sacrifices are all in vain because of your choice.

Params[3]: No...
He reaches out with his trembling hand, hoping to hold onto some of the shattered fragments, but the crowd steps on his fingers just as they did the broken device.
Give it back...!
The excruciating pain in his chest torments his soul.
Has he made the wrong choice? Should he have listened to Rachel and given everything to Ashlar?
—No! That is not the path he dreams of!

Params[1]: Is this the path you dream of, then?

Params[3]: ...No... It isn't... All I wanted was...
—a people that does not have to starve or be exploited. A people that is treated fairly with the decencies of life!
As his voiceless declaration disappears amidst the chanting crowd, the dreams of the tens of thousands of people on the lower level also vanish in the dark like a dying ember.
Kid's still alive.
Throw him off the train.
